Let's be honest - we've all done it. Kept that underperforming rep too long because...

The temporary discomfort of making a change will always beat the permanent pain of settling.

posts.name:
Neil Wood
Neil Wood
posts.content:
Continuous Learning: 
A Key to Sales Success

"Always be learning" is a mantra that top salespeople have ingrained in their professional DNA.

While the old adage of "always be selling" was once the rallying cry for many sales teams, I believe a more effective approach is to "always be willing to learn something new, enhance your skills, and consistently build relationships."

Some clients may desire a deeper connection, while others may not, but establishing a foundation of trust and respect is always a worthwhile endeavor.





Click this link for today‚Äôs video:

comments.commentText: Agreed! Continuous learning and genuine relationships are key to lasting sales success. Trust and adaptability make all the difference!

Thank you Neil. 
Let‚Äôs connect this week. I‚Äôll check your calendly when I get home from two hours at the gym.

posts.name:
Chris James L.
Chris James L.

üî¨Dave Breshears
üî¨Dave Breshears
posts.content:
I decided to work with Remington Rawlings over my 54th birthday dinner, after Outreach's Unleash conference in early October 2023. 

I came to the conference with very different plans for my future, but I left with a clear vision of what I wanted to do next.

Remington and I have been coming at the same problem from two different directions for the better part of the past decade.

We both started as SDRs, me just a couple of years before him in spite of our considerable age difference.

His SDR pedigree includes a stint atbefore transitioning into RevOps at(acquired), then Head of Marketing Ops at(acquired by Facebook), before landing at, running SDR RevOps under the legendary.

I didn't know any of those things that night at dinner, only that he'd worked at Snowflake and Lars trusted him.

But over the course of that meal, it became crystal clear that we shared a vision about how to do Sales Development right, and an understanding of why so many organizations struggled.

Remington came to this understanding by going deep with some of the most sophisticated revenue organizations on the planet.

I came to it after working with hundreds of companies, seeing the same problems over, and over, and over.

Over the next year, we worked together to bring this shared vision to life, in the form of.

What is that shared vision and understanding?

The best Sales Development organizations aren't focused on scale and velocity. Doing more turns out to be a good way to get a lot less out of your revenue engine.

Slowing down, thinking smaller, and going deeper delivered better results - consistently, and for all sorts of companies.

But that's easier said than done, and harder still because the tools required to make a well-orchestrated Sales Development engine function simply didn't exist.

That's why Remington built, and why I'm excited to join his team and help him introduce it to the world.

We're starting by helping companies understand exactly where they stand, shining a light into the dark corners of their revenue engine to expose the primary impediments to success.

If your Sales Development engine is a black box, we can open it up and show you what's really happening.

If you're not getting the results you want from your pipeline generation efforts, we can help you understand why - and what to do about it.

Want to know how you can get more performance out of your revenue engine?

Let's talk.

posts.name:
Sam McNaull
Sam McNaull
posts.content:
Don‚Äôt throw the Security Control handbook at your client.

80-100 targeted baseline controls instead of every single one with enhancements.

A great insight from client conversations.

Throwing the Book at Security Controls Isn't the Answer

Dos:
‚Ü≥ Focus on 80-100 targeted and repeated controls...start with 5 if you need to. Create repeatable patterns for faster future evidence collection and assessments.
‚Ü≥ Use threat scenarios for management context
‚Ü≥ Tailor security assessments

Don'ts:
‚Ü≥ Apply all controls blindly
‚Ü≥ Ignore specific threat scenarios
‚Ü≥ Use one-size-fits-all assessments

This client‚Äôs perspective came from working with multiple federal departments wrestling with control overload. Their security teams were drowning in documentation rather than defending against real threats.

Tailored security assessments beat generic ones every time. Clients report significantly faster implementation and better threat coverage when we focus on their specific risk scenarios.

This approach isn't just theoretical, it's practical. One department reduced their control assessment time by 60% (5 months to 2 months) while improving their security posture.

The world of security compliance is complex and challenging enough. Simplifying it and do not be an obstacle to your clients but work with them to create the targeted controls list to stay ahead.
